Comment: I mean, the equity is about providing more broadband to Americans. It has nothing to do with race, especially since a bunch of it is for RURAL Internet access which is mostly white people.   As to the analogy I like the analogy: imagine you are running a marathon. Your legs and arms are shackled together with heavy chains, and occasionally someone from the sidelines hits you in the face with a stick. No one else in the marathon is tied up or hit.  Then part way through the race they take the chains off. Everyone says "well now you are equal!" People still get to hit you in the face with sticks, and you are MILES behind the other people in the race. When you try to complain, people hit you with bigger sticks.   Later, they make a new rule that people aren't allowed to hit you with sticks anymore. People complain, even say that hitting you with sticks HELPS you! It encouraged you to run faster! Yes, you are black and blue with bruises, and you have a fracture in one of your legs which never healed right. In fact, during the fight just to GET the No Hitting With Sticks, a bunch of them showed up and stopped you so they could beat you EXTRA hard. But now there's a No Sticks Rule, you still have a fracture, you are bleeding, and you are told that you are now on a totally even, fair marathon.  And then, miles and miles later, you find out that this whole time, the other people in the marathon were taking breaks. They got water and food. You never even were TOLD there were rest stops, because by the time you got there, all those benefits were gone. Or worse, when they took the chains off, or made the No Sticks Rule, they also secretly made a rule getting rid of those rest stops. They even set fire to them, making sure nobody could ever use them, JUST to make sure YOU couldn't use them, too.  And now, people are finishing the marathon. You are so far behind that the first people who finished the marathon aren't even aware there are still people running. They showered and are attending parties, oblivious to the fact that you're not even halfway through it. Some of them are denying a marathon ever existed, in fact.

Comment: No, those people are just lying. They all know the history, and are actively living through it just like the rest of us. You cannot live to be an adult in America without understanding the legacy of slavery and the colonizers' ongoing genocide against Native Americans. I'm black, and I'm 2 degrees of separation from a former slave (my great-grandmother, who died in 2019, would tell us about her grandmother, who was enslaved). And I'm only in my 20s! This wasn't very long ago, they haven't just forgotten.  Even as they began telling the lie of Thanksgiving and teaching it to their children, they were actively witnessing and participating in the land theft, forced deportations, and mass murders against Native Americans across the country. We all learn better than to believe in the story of Thanksgiving eventually just like we stop believing in Santa Claus, but our kids still come home from school with hand-shaped paper turkeys and pilgrim hats every year.  Those conservatives we're talking about are still living in a culture built by the Confederates and their ancestors. Their culture has taught them that it's virtuous to lie about the atrocities they've built their lives on, and honorable to kill and die over their lies. It is the foundation of their national and personal identities.  Lying about having stepped on the black kid's head to climb the fence is an honorable, respectable, and required part of participating in civil society for them. If they *don't* lie about slavery and racism—or, say, the Big Lie about the 2020 election—even their own family won't be civil with them at the dinner table.

Comment: Ehm, seems pretty normal to me. People have gone deeper on this area since. Not a general concern at this point. Almost any IoT drvice with Linux could be said to “be setup to spy on users”. I am an actual security expert and without more evidence this is nothing. Almost every system ships with tcpdump and other packet logging tools for debugging. And many home router lets the owners access them for updates and such. Your data is generally safe due to application layer cryptography such as TLS, etc. it isn’t great the network operator can access the device, but it is pretty normal. Teslas, fords and many other consumer devices grant the device manufacturer privileged access.  Either you trust StarLink or not, the device set up does not really tell you much.

Author: donorcycle

Comment: It isn't government subsidies that pay for rural internet in most places, it's the land owners. They don't just get $1 million from the government and say, "hey, let's go run fiber to that farm out there". A lot of the time rural people just got screwed; google the $200 billion in tax breaks story, or the $42 billion in rural broadband subsidies that connected nobody, and so on; there's been programs over the years meant to expand or make rural broadband ubiquitous, but it never happens. There was supposedly billions spent on connecting rural places to broadband and it didn't happen.           What does happen if you're out there in the sticks and want fiber rolled in, is they bill you. The landowner pays the cost. It's not a subsidy paying that cost, it's the houses where the fiber is installed. Rural subsidies in some places might keep the cost per month down after an installation to $50 a month, if they're lucky, but usually not (and that all expired last year anyway, if I recall). If you want service somewhere where the ISP didn't judge you worth spending the money to install the infrastructure to begin with, you pay the tens of thousands for the fiber rollout and the pole installs and everything else. And then, if you're really lucky, you might get to pay less than $120 a month for shitty rural broadband.

Comment: Keep money in the local economy or siphon it to the richest man on the planet? Easy choice for Republicans   At least in my dad's area, it was $90/mo for 500mbit local fiber versus $120 for  300mbit on starlink. I think there's an installation fee but you could very easily sell your Starlink equipment plus a year of savings on the fiber line to recover it. Then it's more reliable, provides jobs to the service crews needed for rollout and maintenance, and in many areas it's owned by a rural co-op so the customers have a say.   Like what a refresh from Spectrum and Charter and those other huge corporations.   And I mean, Starlink is awesome, don't get me wrong.. like I recently went on a 3 day hike through the Andes and this random hostel at the bottom of a canyon that was 100% solar powered.. they had Starlink internet.

Comment: SF internet situation is actually very unevenly distributed. The city deliberately disobeys state law on fiber micro-trenching, and trolleybus power lines can impede some work in neighborhoods with overhead wires. For the unlucky who cannot get fiber, this means - you guessed it - Xfinity, which has only updated half of the city with mid-split.  Meanwhile, my grandma in Colorado has 10 gig fiber.  I am of course very thankful that I don’t have to use AT&T DSL. That would be a true nightmare.  Anyway, my point is that the rural neighborhoods are somehow getting a better product because there is less bureaucracy in the buildout, but it’s sad that it is likely to be torpedoed by Trump.
